prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Contrary to Public Interest—Breaches of the Law

para.paratext: In the case of Steintron International Electronics Ltd. v. Vorberg,[1] the plaintiff applied for an injunction preventing the defendants (all former senior employees of the plaintiff) from working with NEC Corporation, one of Steintron's suppliers. The grounds for the injunction were that in working with NEC Corporation, the defendants were disclosing Steintron's confidential business information and thus breaching restrictive covenants and interfering with Steintron's legitimate business interests. At the time, however, Steintron was ordering and receiving goods from NEC without the ability to pay for them, and was clearing out the goods as quickly as possible so that NEC could not trace Steintron's assets. This constituted fraud, and thus the court dismissed the action for breach of confidential information because fraud is an exception to the confidentiality rule.[2]

In Canadian Javelin Ltd. v. Sparling,[3] the plaintiff sought an injunction preventing the defendant, Sparling, from conducting an investigation for the Restrictive Trade Practices Commission and thus from disclosing confidential business information to third parties. Sparling and an associate had seized and copied thousands of the plaintiff's documents and, in some cases, copies were sent to the Quebec Securities Commission and the U.S. Securities Exchange Commission, both of which were investigating the plaintiff for fraud. It was held that Sparling was entitled to disclose the information received to any person who had a public interest in receiving it because he was carrying out a public purpose. Disclosure to the relevant officials of the Quebec Securities Commission and the U.S. Securities Exchange Commission was appropriate since disclosure was for the purpose of assisting them in their investigation.[4]

Upon termination of employment, an employer is still entitled to enforce reasonable non-competition and non-solicitation clauses contained in employment contracts. An employer is also entitled to rely on such clauses despite an allegation that the employer has breached the contract of employment. Any such breach can be remedied by way of damages and does not go to the root of the contract so as to disentitle the employer from relying on the non-competition and non-solicitation clauses contained in the contract.[5]
Steintron International Electronics Ltd. v. Vorberg (1986), 10 C.P.R. (3d) 393 (B.C.S.C.).
